questions.text: A 42-year-old man with HIV infection comes to the physician because of several episodes of rectal bleeding over the past 2 weeks. He has had pain around the anal area for the past month. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with esophageal candidiasis and was treated with oral fluconazole. He has had 9 male sexual partners over his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. The patient's current medications include dolutegravir, tenofovir, and emtricitabine. He is 179 cm (5 ft 10 in) and weighs 66 kg (146 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show a hard 2-cm mass palpable 0.5 cm above the anal verge that bleeds on contact. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 95/mm3. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following interventions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The incidence of anal canal SCC is higher in individuals that are immunodeficient (e.g., due to HIV infection) and in men who have sex with men (MSM), such as this patient. The combination of chemotherapy and radiation is the treatment of choice for patients with anal canal SCC. Subsequent surgery is only indicated if a residual tumor is confirmed with biopsy after the completion of radiochemotherapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominoperineal resection (APR) was formerly the treatment of choice in patients with anal canal SCC. However, a less radical treatment option has been established that has been shown to have higher survival rates than APR. APR is indicated in patients with low-lying rectal adenocarcinomas that can not be treated with sphincter-sparing procedures and those with anal canal adenocarcinomas. Anal canal adenocarcinoma, however, is rare and arises above the dentate line.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical cytodestructive treatment with trichloroacetic acid is indicated in patients with anogenital warts (i.e., condylomata acuminata), for which HIV infection and unprotected sexual intercourse are risk factors. However, condylomata acuminata are usually asymptomatic. They are painful only in a small percentage of cases, and rectal bleeding is a rare sequela. Topical trichloroacetic acid therapy is not appropriate for the treatment of anal canal cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Total mesorectal excision is usually performed in combination with low anterior resection in patients with rectal adenocarcinoma. However, the patient's tumor is just above the anal verge, within the anal canal, rather than the rectum. In addition, rectal adenocarcinoma is unlikely in a young patient without predisposing factors such as inflammatory bowel disease or a family history of colorectal cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

Injection sclerotherapy is used in the treatment of patients with rectal prolapse. Rectal prolapse may present with an anal mass and possibly with bleeding, but the mass tends to be painless and typically exhibits radial (partial prolapse) or concentric (full-thickness prolapse) mucosal folds. Furthermore, the patient does not have fecal incontinence, which does occur in most patients with rectal prolapse, nor does he have predisposing factors for this condition such as elevated intraabdominal pressure (e.g., due to constipation or chronic cough) or weakness of the pelvic floor muscles (e.g., due to advanced age or previous perineal surgery).

F) INCORRECT:

Submucosal hemorrhoidectomy is indicated for the treatment of grade IV internal hemorrhoids and lower-grade internal hemorrhoids that are resistant to initial treatment. While internal hemorrhoids may present as an anal mass with bright red bleeding, digital rectal examination and anoscopy would reveal a mass arising above the dentate line rather than just above the anal verge.
questions.hint: Anal canal cancer typically presents as an exophytic, hard anal mass that is often tender and bleeds easily. Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common histological type of anal canal cancer (approx. 90% of cases) and it typically arises just above the anal verge and below the dentate line, which is located approx. 2 cm away from the anal verge.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of rectal bleeding and itching for 2 weeks. During this period, he has also had pain with defecation. Four months ago, he was diagnosed with anogenital warts that were treated with cryotherapy. Over the past year, he has been sexually active with 3 male partners. He uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications are zidovudine, emtricitabine, and efavirenz. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show an exophytic mass on the anal margin that is protruding into the anal canal. The mass is tender to palpation and bleeds easily on contact. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 7,600/mm3 and a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count of 410/mm3. A biopsy specimen of the lesion shows a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following cellular processes was most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's malignancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Activation of the c-myc proto-oncogene is associated with infection with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV), an oncogenic virus that can cause endemic Burkitt lymphoma. c-myc codes for a transcription factor that, when overexpressed, leads to unregulated cell proliferation and differentiation. In most cases of Burkitt lymphoma, the overactivation of c-myc is due to the translocation t(8;14). However, the c-myc gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

B) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of the von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) tumor suppressor gene due to a loss-of-function mutation can lead to von Hippel-Lindau disease. VHL is a protein involved in the degradation of hypoxia-inducible factor 1a (HIF-1). Deletion of VHL results in increased activity of HIF-1, which induces the transcription of target genes involved in the response to hypoxia (e.g., EPO and VEGF). VHL disease causes hemangioblastomas, bilateral renal cell carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma; however, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the VHL gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

C) INCORRECT:

Activation of the TAX proto-oncogene is associated with infection with human T-lymphotropic virus type I (HTLV-I), an oncogenic virus that can cause adult T-cell leukemia (ATL). Once a CD4+ T-cell is infected by HTLV-I, TAX induces overexpression of stimulatory host transcription factors (e.g., NF-kB), which leads to uncontrolled T-cell proliferation. However, the TAX gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

D) INCORRECT:

Inactivation of Wilms tumor 1 (WT1) gene, a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for a transcription factor responsible for urogenital development, is caused by a loss-of-function mutation and can lead to malignancy (e.g., nephroblastoma) or genomic syndromes (e.g., Denys-Drash syndrome, WAGR syndrome). However, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the WT1 gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

E) INCORRECT:

Activation of the KRAS gene, a proto-oncogene that encodes for a GTPase involved in the regulation of cell growth, is caused by a point mutation and has been implicated in the development of several cancers, including pancreatic adenocarcinoma, non-small cell lung cancer, and colorectal cancer. However, it is not associated with anal squamous cell carcinoma. Moreover, the KRAS gene is not involved in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with HPV-16 and HPV-18.

F) CORRECT:

Inactivation of the tumor suppressor proteins p53 and retinoblastoma protein (pRb) is implicated in the pathogenesis of malignancy caused by infection with the oncogenic viruses HPV-16 and HPV-18. HPV-16 produces oncoprotein E6, which inhibits p53. Oncoprotein E7 is produced by HPV-18 and inhibits pRb. Inactivation of these proteins leads to the continued growth and proliferation of damaged cells. General risk factors for the development of anal cancer include immunocompromised status (e.g., HIV), receptive anal intercourse, and infection with HPV (e.g., anogenital warts). HPV-16 and HPV-18 are also involved in the development of cervical, oral, and oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinomas.

Kaposi sarcoma, a malignancy strongly associated with HIV, is also caused by an oncogenic virus, HHV-8. This herpesvirus infects human endothelial cells and transforms them into neoplastic spindle cells via various oncogenic products that affect cell cycle regulation and apoptosis.
questions.hint: Infection with oncogenic human papillomavirus (HPV) strains likely played a role in the development of this patient's anal cancer.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of pain with defecation, anal itching, and blood in the stool. Over the past month, she has also had a 4-kg (9-lb) weight loss. She has a history of irritable bowel syndrome, HIV infection, and human papillomavirus infection. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 37.5C (99.5F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Examination of the perianal region shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a tender mass and bright red blood in the anal canal. Anoscopy shows an exophytic, ulcerated, 2.5-cm mass that is located just above the anocutaneous line and below the dentate line. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A fibroepithelial polyp of the anus can manifest as an exophytic lesion in the perianal region. However, patients are usually asymptomatic. Moreover, fibroepithelial polyps of the anus arise from anal columns at the dentate line rather than near the anocutaneous line.

B) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) of the anus manifests as an exophytic, bleeding perianal mass. Besides being very rare (the main risk factor for BCC is sun exposure), BCC of the anus arises below rather than above the anocutaneous line. Moreover, although this condition is associated with immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection), it is not associated with HPV infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Internal hemorrhoids can manifest with anal pruritus, hematochezia, and a palpable mass on digital rectal examination. Furthermore, in a patient with irritable bowel syndrome, constipation is a common feature and a risk factor for developing hemorrhoids. However, internal hemorrhoids more commonly appear as dilated, purple or blue veins on anoscopy rather than an exophytic ulcerated mass, and, because they arise from the superior hemorrhoidal plexus, they are located above the dentate line rather than the anocutaneous line. Moreover, defecation is usually painless and weight loss is not expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Condylomata acuminata of the anus is caused by HPV infection, which this patient has a history of, and can manifest as an exophytic lesion. However, although condylomata acuminata are pruritic, tender, and friable in a small percentage of cases, they are more commonly asymptomatic; weight loss is not expected. Moreover, when present in the anal canal, condylomata acuminata usually appear as small papules rather than large, ulcerated lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Paget disease of the anus can manifest with anal pruritus, pain with defecation, and hematochezia, all of which are seen here. However, besides being extremely rare, this condition usually manifests as well-demarcated erythematous plaques or patches with a white scale rather than a single ulcerated, exophytic lesion.

F) CORRECT:

A history of hematochezia, anal pruritus, painful defecation, and weight loss in a patient with an exophytic, friable, ulcerated mass above the anal verge is suggestive of anal canal cancer. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological type of anal canal cancer and typically arises below the dentate line (see Characteristics of the anal canal above and below the dentate line table). Patients must undergo a biopsy of the tumor to confirm the diagnosis. Women diagnosed with anal canal squamous cell carcinoma should also undergo a gynecological examination for cervical cancer screening.
questions.hint: A history of immunodeficiency (e.g., caused by HIV infection) and prior human papillomavirus (HPV) infection are major risk factors for this condition.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man with HIV infection and a history of genital warts presents for evaluation of a perianal mass. Physical examination reveals verrucous papules on the penis and a large verrucous perianal mass (figure). There is no palpable lymphadenopathy.
In addition to surgical removal and close histopathological examination of the perianal lesion, which one of the following evaluations should be performed?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is not indicated as initial evaluations in a patient with condyloma acuminata.

B) CORRECT:

Anal condyloma is one of the most common sexually transmitted diseases and can predispose to anal cancer. Anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata) are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and are most commonly associated with HPV types 6 or 11, although several other types are also associated. HPV types 16 and 18 carry the highest rate of malignant degeneration.

When anal warts are observed on visual examination or there are worrisome findings on digital rectal examination, patients should be referred for anoscopy with biopsy of lesions to evaluate for the presence of internal condyloma and anal cancer. In addition, because urethral lesions may be present, examination should also include assessment of this anatomic area.

HPV testing can help stratify patients in terms of their risk for neoplastic progression to cancer and may be performed on an individual basis.

Key learning point: Patients with perianal condyloma should be evaluated for internal anal condyloma and anal cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

CT of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated as initial evaluations in a patient with condyloma acuminata.

D) INCORRECT:

When anal warts are observed on visual examination or there are worrisome findings on digital rectal examination, patients should be referred for anoscopy with biopsy of lesions to evaluate for the presence of internal condyloma and anal cancer. Human papillomavirus testing can help stratify patients in terms of their risk for neoplastic progression to cancer and may be performed on an individual basis.

E) INCORRECT:

Biopsy would be indicated if the lesions were atypical in order to rule out malignant degeneration.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 2-month history of pain with defecation, anal itching, and blood in the stool. Current medications include a combined antiretroviral treatment regimen and an oral contraceptive. She is sexually active with one male partner. questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with a three-month history of intermittent rectal bleeding. He initially attributed this to hemorrhoids, but now reports a persistent sensation of fullness and mild pain with defecation. His medical history is significant for HIV, well-controlled on antiretroviral therapy, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. On examination, vital signs are stable. Digital rectal examination reveals a 2-cm, firm, ulcerated, non-mobile lesion on the posterior wall of the anal canal. Non-tender, right-sided inguinal lymphadenopathy is also noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anal fissure causes pain and bleeding with defecation, and the posterior location is typical. However, a fissure is a linear tear in the mucosa, not a 2-cm firm, ulcerated mass. While a chronic fissure may have a sentinel tag, it would not be described as a non-mobile, firm mass, nor would it typically cause inguinal lymphadenopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Adenocarcinoma of the rectum is plausible given the patient's age and symptoms of bleeding and a mass. However, rectal cancers typically metastasize to perirectal and internal iliac nodes, whereas this patient has inguinal adenopathy.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's risk factors (HIV infection, smoking), chronic symptoms, and physical exam findings are classic for squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the anal canal. Most cases are caused by human papillomavirus, and immunosuppression and smoking are major co-factors for malignant transformation. The anal canal is lined by squamous epithelium, making SCC the predominant histology. The exam reveals a firm, ulcerated, non-mobile mass, features highly suggestive of malignancy. Crucially, the presence of inguinal lymphadenopathy reflects the lymphatic drainage pattern of the anal canal below the dentate line, indicating regional metastasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Perianal abscess may manifest as a painful mass in a patient with HIV. However, an abscess is an acute infection manifesting with severe, throbbing pain, erythema, and a fluctuant, tender mass, often with fever. This patient's three-month history and firm, non-mobile, ulcerated lesion are not consistent with an acute abscess.

E) INCORRECT:

This is plausible as it can cause a painful perianal lump and bleeding. However, a thrombosed hemorrhoid presents acutely with severe pain and a tender, bluish nodule. This patient has a three-month history, a firm, ulcerated, non-mobile lesion, and non-tender lymphadenopathy, all of which are inconsistent with this diagnosis.
questions.hint: The lymphatic drainage to the inguinal nodes is a key clue to the anatomical origin of this mass.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of well-controlled HIV presents with a three-month history of rectal bleeding and a sensation of a palpable lump. He initially attributed his symptoms to hemorrhoids, but over-the-counter treatments provided no relief. Physical examination shows a 2.5-cm, firm, ulcerated mass in the anal canal, approximately 2 cm proximal to the dentate line. Anoscopy and subsequent biopsy confirm invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Staging workup shows no evidence of distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The standard of care for non-metastatic, localized anal SCC (Stages IIII) is concurrent chemoradiation. This approach, often called the Nigro protocol, combines external beam radiation with chemotherapy, typically 5-fluorouracil and mitomycin C. The chemotherapy acts as a radiosensitizer, enhancing the effectiveness of the radiation. This regimen offers high cure rates while preserving the anal sphincter, thus avoiding a permanent colostomy. This patient's well-controlled HIV is a significant risk factor for anal SCC (strongly associated with human papillomavirus infection) but is not a contraindication to this curative-intent therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Although radiation therapy is a critical component of treatment, using it as a single modality is less effective than combining it with chemotherapy. Clinical trials have shown that the addition of sensitizing chemotherapy to radiation significantly improves local control and overall survival rates for localized anal cancer. Therefore, radiation alone is considered a suboptimal initial treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Wide local excision may be an option for very small (typically < 2 cm), well-differentiated, superficial tumors located on the anal margin (perianal skin) that do not involve the sphincter complex. This patient's tumor is 2.5 cm, invasive, and located within the anal canal, making it unsuitable for local excision, which would risk incomplete resection and damage to the sphincter.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic chemotherapy alone is the primary treatment for metastatic (Stage IV) anal SCC, in which the goal is palliative. For localized disease with curative intent, chemotherapy alone is insufficient to achieve local control and is only used as a radiosensitizing agent in combination with radiation therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Abdominoperineal resection is a radical surgery involving removal of the anus, rectum, and sigmoid colon, resulting in a permanent colostomy. Although this was the historical treatment for anal cancer, it is now reserved for salvage therapy in cases of persistent or recurrent disease after chemoradiation is unsuccessful. It is not the appropriate initial treatment for localized anal SCC because of its high morbidity and the excellent outcomes of organ-sparing therapy.
questions.hint: The primary treatment goal for localized anal squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is organ preservation with a curative intent. The standard-of-care protocol combines two treatment modalities to achieve this.
